and it's time for a review of the new

um Ben Reaper three Old Testament this
is a brand new LP from Michigan rapper
Baby Tron who's been building up a very
strong and passionate cult following for
several years now the results a recent
double XL Freshman Class placement and
having become one of the most talked
about rappers of this current generation
and it's easy to see why given his
Unique Style his nearly deadpan delivery
with which he rattles off this endless
stream of bars like a machine shooting
off rapid fire references double
entendras and ridiculous one-liners
which cover an array of bases but
usually come back to some key themes
like scamming crime uh also you know
reference to a relative of his that he
lovingly refers to as unki so in a lot
of ways what baby Tron lacks in energy
on his tracks he makes up for in content
and on top of that he seems to
surprisingly be able to wrap over nearly
anything he even tries his hand at a
drill beat on this project and it
manages to be one of the better Cuts
here though the kind of grooves baby
Tron made his name on come straight out
of the sweet and jittery rhythms of 80s
freestyle music which isn't exactly the
most likely genre of music to rap over
these days but somehow it works for him
though it does seem like more recently
baby tron's been doing what he can to
spit over a wider variety of
instrumentals either way with a project
from him you know the beat choices are
going to be unique and sometimes
confusing because you know the sample
material on some of these tracks he is
just saying [ __ ] it in terms of clearing
this and he's just spitting over it one
thing about baby Tron though as distinct
as his sound and style are he hasn't
always proven to be the most versatile
rapper out there and that's made some of
his records so far sound a little
one-dimensional though his first bin
Reaper project from 2019 is so raw and
hilarious it's hard not to be head over
heels for it at least a little bit but
now in 2022 we have progressed all the
way to bin Reaper 3 which I think has a
great balance with a tight run of tracks
that span 40 minutes a decent amount of
variety happening on the production side
died some good choruses being thrown
into these tracks here and there as well
as opposed to the uninterrupted lyrical
Uzi spray we typically hear on tron's
tracks be that on MySpace or one side of
things or the closing cut 365 day grind
a self-portrait of sorts of baby tron's
tireless work ethic which I can't really
deny given his prolific output the chill
keys and relaxed trap beat on this track
make the perfect soundtrack for baby
tron's effortlessly smooth flows we get
a lot of personal background on this cut
as well as on the opener too which gives
a really sharp lyrical rundown of a lot
of the major key career points that has
brought baby Tron to this point like if
you've been kind of out of the know this
track will in fact catch you up though I
don't think his somewhat low energy
performance and the atmosphere kind of
washed out instrumental he's riding on
is necessarily the best reflection of
him playing to his strengths still I
can't deny how good the lyrical focus on
this track is as well as on the song
airtron which has this Speedy run of NBA
a references from start to finish a lot
of which are pretty funny very clever
this song also doubles as one of many
spots on this record where the

these killer vocal Harmony samples

quite good too then there's the song

choppy I think the various changes
across the track Rage Quit for example

and of course because it's baby Tron

so yeah this one sadly is uh far from

with that being said I enjoyed Ben

uh exciting project from front to back
it is his most I think um intentional
his most methodically put together and
